issue.title: Gazebo issues on Windows Subsystem for Linux (WSL)
Gazebo issues on Windows Subsystem for Linux (WSL)

content.raw:
I found some notes on this from last September, and given that I am not working on this I will copy them here, so they can be useful if someone wants to work on this issue.

# 400 ns resolution for `CLOCK_MONOTONIC` 
Even switching from using `CLOCK_REALTIME` to `CLOCK_MONOTONIC`, there is still a major difference between Ubuntu on Windows and the native Ubuntu, that is the resolution of the clock. This is the output of this example program https://gist.github.com/traversaro/e031b324dd278acbd033059e3604ed3f in native Ubuntu running on a Intel Core i7-6500U CPU : 
~~~
traversaro@turati:~/src/time_res_check/build$ ./time_res_check 
--> Testing POSIX APIs
    Error macros values: 
    EINTR : 4
    EINVAL: 22
    ENOTSUP: 95
    Testing CLOCK_MONOTONIC 
    clock_getres return value: 0 with errno 0, 
    resolution: 1 nanoseconds.
    Testing CLOCK_REALTIME 
    clock_getres return value: 0 with errno 0, 
    resolution: 1 nanoseconds.
    Testing CLOCK_PROCESS_CPUTIME_ID 
    clock_getres return value: 0 with errno 0, 
    resolution: 1 nanoseconds.
    Testing CLOCK_THREAD_CPUTIME_ID  
    clock_getres return value: 0 with errno 0, 
    resolution: 1 nanoseconds.
--> Testing C++ APIs
    Testing std::chrono::high_resolution_clock 
    resolution: 1 nanoseconds.
    Testing std::chrono::system_clock 
    resolution: 1 nanoseconds.
    Testing std::chrono::steady_clock 
    resolution: 1 nanoseconds.
~~~
The same program running on WSL on the same processor returns:
~~~
traversaro@LAPTOP-TO4SAKLB:~/src/time_res_check$ ./build/time_res_check
--> Testing POSIX APIs
    Error macros values:
    EINTR : 4
    EINVAL: 22
    ENOTSUP: 95
    Testing CLOCK_MONOTONIC
    clock_getres return value: 0 with errno 0,
    resolution: 400 nanoseconds.
    Testing CLOCK_REALTIME
    clock_getres return value: 0 with errno 0,
    resolution: 400 nanoseconds.
    Testing CLOCK_PROCESS_CPUTIME_ID
    clock_getres return value: -1 with errno 22,
    resolution: 0 nanoseconds.
    Testing CLOCK_THREAD_CPUTIME_ID
    clock_getres return value: -1 with errno 22,
    resolution: 0 nanoseconds.
--> Testing C++ APIs
    Testing std::chrono::high_resolution_clock
    resolution: 1 nanoseconds.
    Testing std::chrono::system_clock
    resolution: 1 nanoseconds.
    Testing std::chrono::steady_clock
    resolution: 1 nanoseconds.
~~~

In a nutshell, the resolution of the clocks in Linux is reported to be 1ns, while on Linux on Windows is reported to be 400 ns. Interestingly the C++11 classes report a period of 1 ns in both cases, but I still have to investigate this. Back in September 2017, this was creating a lot of  warnings similar to `"warning [Time.cc.205] Sleep time is larger than clock resolution, skipping sleep"`, due to this line #!/osrf/gazebo/src/01c7f8b1d68448bc618b575ad1c7ec13fee2b87f/gazebo/common/Time.cc#lines-451 .

Related ROS2 issue: https://github.com/ros2/rcutils/issues/43#issuecomment-320954506 .
content.html:
I found some notes on this from last September, and given that I am not working on this I will copy them here, so they can be useful if someone wants to work on this issue.

400 ns resolution for CLOCK_MONOTONIC

Even switching from using CLOCK_REALTIME to CLOCK_MONOTONIC, there is still a major difference between Ubuntu on Windows and the native Ubuntu, that is the resolution of the clock. This is the output of this example program https://gist.github.com/traversaro/e031b324dd278acbd033059e3604ed3f in native Ubuntu running on a Intel Core i7-6500U CPU : 

traversaro@turati:~/src/time_res_check/build$ ./time_res_check 
--> Testing POSIX APIs
    Error macros values: 
    EINTR : 4
    EINVAL: 22
    ENOTSUP: 95
    Testing CLOCK_MONOTONIC 
    clock_getres return value: 0 with errno 0, 
    resolution: 1 nanoseconds.
    Testing CLOCK_REALTIME 
    clock_getres return value: 0 with errno 0, 
    resolution: 1 nanoseconds.
    Testing CLOCK_PROCESS_CPUTIME_ID 
    clock_getres return value: 0 with errno 0, 
    resolution: 1 nanoseconds.
    Testing CLOCK_THREAD_CPUTIME_ID  
    clock_getres return value: 0 with errno 0, 
    resolution: 1 nanoseconds.
--> Testing C++ APIs
    Testing std::chrono::high_resolution_clock 
    resolution: 1 nanoseconds.
    Testing std::chrono::system_clock 
    resolution: 1 nanoseconds.
    Testing std::chrono::steady_clock 
    resolution: 1 nanoseconds.

The same program running on WSL on the same processor returns:

traversaro@LAPTOP-TO4SAKLB:~/src/time_res_check$ ./build/time_res_check
--> Testing POSIX APIs
    Error macros values:
    EINTR : 4
    EINVAL: 22
    ENOTSUP: 95
    Testing CLOCK_MONOTONIC
    clock_getres return value: 0 with errno 0,
    resolution: 400 nanoseconds.
    Testing CLOCK_REALTIME
    clock_getres return value: 0 with errno 0,
    resolution: 400 nanoseconds.
    Testing CLOCK_PROCESS_CPUTIME_ID
    clock_getres return value: -1 with errno 22,
    resolution: 0 nanoseconds.
    Testing CLOCK_THREAD_CPUTIME_ID
    clock_getres return value: -1 with errno 22,
    resolution: 0 nanoseconds.
--> Testing C++ APIs
    Testing std::chrono::high_resolution_clock
    resolution: 1 nanoseconds.
    Testing std::chrono::system_clock
    resolution: 1 nanoseconds.
    Testing std::chrono::steady_clock
    resolution: 1 nanoseconds.

In a nutshell, the resolution of the clocks in Linux is reported to be 1ns, while on Linux on Windows is reported to be 400 ns. Interestingly the C++11 classes report a period of 1 ns in both cases, but I still have to investigate this. Back in September 2017, this was creating a lot of warnings similar to "warning [Time.cc.205] Sleep time is larger than clock resolution, skipping sleep", due to this line #!/osrf/gazebo/src/01c7f8b1d68448bc618b575ad1c7ec13fee2b87f/gazebo/common/Time.cc#lines-451 .

Related ROS2 issue: https://github.com/ros2/rcutils/issues/43#issuecomment-320954506 .

issue.title: Gazebo issues on Windows Subsystem for Linux (WSL)

content.raw:
November 2018 Update: 

 *  `IP_MULTICAST_IF` was indeed solved in recent Windows 10 releases 
 * `CLOCK_REALTIME` is still not supported in WSL, see https://github.com/Microsoft/BashOnWindows/issues/2503 . Switching to `CLOCK_MONOTONIC` seems to be the most natural solution on this

Given that we are currently using Gazebo on WSL in my group, I just opened two PRs to solve the most pressing problems: 

* #!/osrf/gazebo/pull-requests/3036 
* #!/osrf/gazebo/pull-requests/3037

Once these PRs are merged, I think we can close this issue.
content.html:
November 2018 Update:

  • IP_MULTICAST_IF was indeed solved in recent Windows 10 releases
  • CLOCK_REALTIME is still not supported in WSL, see https://github.com/Microsoft/BashOnWindows/issues/2503 . Switching to CLOCK_MONOTONIC seems to be the most natural solution on this

Given that we are currently using Gazebo on WSL in my group, I just opened two PRs to solve the most pressing problems:

  • #!/osrf/gazebo/pull-requests/3036
  • #!/osrf/gazebo/pull-requests/3037

Once these PRs are merged, I think we can close this issue.

issue.title: Gazebo issues on Windows Subsystem for Linux (WSL)

content.raw:
The PRs #!/osrf/gazebo/pull-requests/3036 and #!/osrf/gazebo/pull-requests/3037 have been merged. 
There are still some marginal problems. For example, the  "Sleep time is larger than clock resolution, skipping sleep" messages still spam the log files instead of the command line both on WSL and on native Windows build (cc @seanyen-msft that could be interested in this) , but I think we can open a new issue for that, and close this one. 

Thanks a lot to the reviewers!
content.html:
The PRs #!/osrf/gazebo/pull-requests/3036 and #!/osrf/gazebo/pull-requests/3037 have been merged. There are still some marginal problems. For example, the "Sleep time is larger than clock resolution, skipping sleep" messages still spam the log files instead of the command line both on WSL and on native Windows build (cc @seanyen-msft that could be interested in this) , but I think we can open a new issue for that, and close this one.

Thanks a lot to the reviewers!

issue.title: Gazebo issues on Windows Subsystem for Linux (WSL)

content.raw: All the known major issues with Gazebo on WSL have been solved in the latest `gazebo9` branch, either by Gazebo fixes or WSL fixes.
content.html: All the known major issues with Gazebo on WSL have been solved in the latest gazebo9 branch, either by Gazebo fixes or WSL fixes.

issue.title: Gazebo issues on Windows Subsystem for Linux (WSL)

content.raw: These fixes have been released as part of the Gazebo 9.6.0 release.
content.html: These fixes have been released as part of the Gazebo 9.6.0 release.

issue.title: Gazebo issues on Windows Subsystem for Linux (WSL)

content.raw: Small note: a residual issue when running Gazebo on WSL is that you need to set `GAZEBO_IP` to 127.0.0.1, that should not be necessary according to the analysis done in https://github.com/Microsoft/WSL/issues/3368#issuecomment-414900796 by @jbohren-hbr .
content.html: Small note: a residual issue when running Gazebo on WSL is that you need to set GAZEBO_IP to 127.0.0.1, that should not be necessary according to the analysis done in https://github.com/Microsoft/WSL/issues/3368#issuecomment-414900796 by @jbohren-hbr .

issue.title: Gazebo issues on Windows Subsystem for Linux (WSL)

content.raw: Actually also the `GAZEBO_IP` issue was solved by #!/osrf/gazebo/pull-requests/3009/adding-check-to-make-sure-automatic/diff .
content.html: Actually also the GAZEBO_IP issue was solved by #!/osrf/gazebo/pull-requests/3009/adding-check-to-make-sure-automatic/diff .

issue.title: Gazebo issues on Windows Subsystem for Linux (WSL)

content.raw: This also might be effecting builds in docker environments too. This thread was found when debugging https://github.com/ros/rosdistro/pull/19696
content.html: This also might be effecting builds in docker environments too. This thread was found when debugging https://github.com/ros/rosdistro/pull/19696

issue.title: Gazebo issues on Windows Subsystem for Linux (WSL)

content.raw:
The issue clock\_nanosleep with clockid CLOCK\_REALTIME fails with error EINVAL should be finally fixed soon, according to the comment in [https://github.com/microsoft/WSL/issues/4898#issuecomment-592196721](https://github.com/microsoft/WSL/issues/4898#issuecomment-592196721) .

‌
content.html:
The issue clock_nanosleep with clockid CLOCK_REALTIME fails with error EINVAL should be finally fixed soon, according to the comment in https://github.com/microsoft/WSL/issues/4898#issuecomment-592196721 .

‌
